abstract.text: Creates a new immutable array with the given values.
Creates a new immutable array with the values from another array.
Returns the number of values currently in an array.
Retrieves a value at a given index.
Calls a function once for each element in range in an array.
Searches an array for a value using a binary search algorithm.

devLink-1696123.title: Property List Programming Topics for Core Foundation

devLink-1696114.title: Collections Programming Topics for Core Foundation

abstract.text: Reports whether or not a value is in an array.
Counts the number of times a given value occurs in an array.
Searches an array forward for a value.
Searches an array backward for a value.
Fills a buffer with values from an array.
Returns the type identifier for the CFArray opaque type.
Prototype of a callback function that may be applied to every value in an array.
Prototype of a callback function used to get a description of a value in an array.
Prototype of a callback function used to determine if two values in an array are equal.
Prototype of a callback function used to release a value before it’s removed from an array.
Prototype of a callback function used to retain a value being added to an array.
Structure containing the callbacks of a CFArray.
A reference to an immutable array object.
CFArray provides a predefined callback structure appropriate for use when the values in a CFArray are all CFType-derived objects.
The CFFileDescriptor provides an opaque type to monitor file descriptors for read and write activity via CFRunLoop.

CFStringTokenizer allows you to tokenize strings into words, sentences or paragraphs in a language-neutral way. It supports languages such as Japanese and Chinese that do not delimit words by spaces, as well as de-compounding German compounds. You can obtain Latin transcription for tokens. It also provides language identification API.

inlineContent.text: CFArray and its derived mutable type,
, manage ordered collections of values called arrays. CFArray creates static arrays and CFMutableArray creates dynamic arrays.
You create a static array object using either the
or
function. These functions return an array containing the values you pass in as arguments. (Note that arrays can’t contain
pointers; in most cases, though, you can use the

constant instead.) Values are not copied but retained using the retain callback provided when an array was created. Similarly, when a value is removed from an array, it is released using the release callback.
CFArray’s two primitive functions
and
provide the basis for all other functions in its interface. The
function returns the number of elements in an array;
gives you access to an array’s elements by index, with index values starting at 0.
A number of CFArray functions allow you to operate over a range of values in an array, for example
lets you apply a function to values in an array, and
searches an array for the value that matches its parameter. Recall that a range is defined as
, therefore to operate over the entire array the range you supply should be
(where
is the count of the array).
CFArray is “toll-free bridged” with its Cocoa Foundation counterpart,
. This means that the Core Foundation type is interchangeable in function or method calls with the bridged Foundation object. Therefore, in a method where you see an
parameter, you can pass in a
, and in a function where you see a
parameter, you can pass in an NSArray instance. This also applies to concrete subclasses of NSArray. See
for more information on toll-free bridging.
